name: Alex Preston, The Dissenters' Chapel, London (1 March 2012)
description: 7pm Thursday 1 March 2012 This is a past event. Break bread with award-winning writer and journalist Alex Preston, as Literary Dinners embarks on a unique evening of feasting and fiction at the evocative Dissenters’ Chapel in Kensal Green Cemetery. With miraculous nerve, Alex Preston’s new novel The Revelations lays bare a world where the success of a religious cult becomes more important than the lives of its followers. In celebration of the novel’s proselytising prose, pop-up restaurateurs The Two Nightingales have planned a three-course gourmet equivalent to the Last Supper and our resident maître d’fiction will guide the evening's Sermon on the Mount. Tickets included an evening's literary entertainment, 3-course meal and complimentary wine.

name: Evie Wyld, The Society Club, London (27 May 2012)
description: 6pm Sunday 27 May 2012 This is a past event. Nestle into the intimate atmosphere of The Society Club, as Literary Dinners – in an adventure with Foyles! - spend an evening with writer and bookseller-vivant Evie Wyld. We’ll be paying honour to Evie’s debut novel After the Fire, A Still Small Voice, bringing to life three generations of Italian fathers and sons struggling against the hardships of Australia’s east coast. Our pop-up restaurateurs The Two Nightingales will be on hand with a vibrant combination of bakery and bestiary to satiate any outback raconteur, evoking the food and family that form just one ingredient in Evie’s delicious fictional recipe. Tickets included an evening’s literary entertainment, 2-course meal and special handmade gifts.

name: Craig Taylor, Islington Metal Works, London (15 July 2012)
description: 6pm Sunday 15 July 2012 Dine in the unparalleled setting of a transformed iron foundry, the Islington Metal Works, as Literary Dinners and Foyles - whose own literary luncheons are the stuff of legend - join forces to celebrate the epic achievement that is Craig Taylor's Londoners. Craig will be retelling stories from some of the capital's most charismatic inhabitants, moving from table to table with only the juiciest cuts, as pop-up restaurateurs The Two Nightingales offer extra-literary sustenance in the form of hearty English fare. Our modern day literary conductor will be guiding proceedings from the comfort of the Metal Work's tube carriage bar, with a warming welcome close at hand in the shape of specially-crafted Hendrick's Gin cocktails. For an extra 10% off Londoners, enter "TAY10" at the checkout on the Foyles website. Tickets included an evening’s literary entertainment, complimentary Hendrick's Gin cocktail and 3-course meal. Vegetarian option available. In partnership with Foyles and Hendrick's Gin

name: Edward Docx, Oxford Botanic Gardens, Oxford (August 2012)
description: 1pm Saturday 11 August 2012 This is a past event. After hours trekking through the jungle heat, we break stride for a most unusual picnic, offering a cornucopia of tranquillity and literary quiet in the conservatory of the Oxford Botanic Gardens. Nestled among the foliage, our resident guide will welcome guests to a luncheon of over-flowing baskets and sultry tropical treats as Edward Docx, journalist and author of The Devil’s Garden, reads and shares an exclusive insight into his own experiences of the Amazon. Join us for a little rainforest revelry and escape an Olympic summer for the tropics of Oxford. Our local culinary trailblazer, Becky's Kitchen, will offer a suitable heady concoction of South American flavours, evoking the sights, sounds and smells of one of the world’s most mysterious environments. Tickets included a gourmet picnic, entry to the Oxford Botanic Gardens, complimentary Picador gift bag, and lunchtime entertainment. Vegetarian option available. In partnership with:

name: Glyn Dillon, Orange Dot, London (22 September 2012)
description: 6pm Saturday 22 September 2012 This is a past event. Step into the pages of an extraordinary new graphic novel with Literary Dinners, as we get involved in a rather colourful tale of love, life and murderous thoughts. Author and artist Glyn Dillon will transform the Orange Dot Gallery into the alternate reality of his forthcoming graphic novel, The Nao of Brown, a story of one woman’s search for that most elusive love - perfect love. Join us to dine on delicacies that pay tribute to the novel’s Japanese influences, as we bring you a multi-course, multi-taste banquet menu of Godzilla-sized proportions. Our resident maitre d'graphique will be on hand with speech bubbles to guide guests through the evening's novel entertainment, plus special guest Jessica Hynes will be talking with Glyn about his extraordinary work over a fortune cookie or two. Tickets included a multi-course meal and literary entertainment. In partnership with:

name: Sheil Heti, The Rag Factory, London (2 May 2013)
description: 6:30pm Thursday 2 May 2013 This is a past event. What did you want to be as a child? Fire fighter, astronaut… celebrity dragon known for magical deeds? Well, let Literary Dinners take you back, as we get childish and act out at the Rag Factory with Sheila Heti. For one night only, small talk and mundanity will be put aside in favour of 'got got need', lofty dreams and squabbling over the last flump. Much lauded and chit-chatted about, Sheila will be center stage as we try and answer her fictional memoir How Should a Person Be? Accompanied by colourful drawings and a gob-smacking menu from the delectable Kosher Roast, Sheila will be on hand as literary therapist for the evening. Our resident maitre’d fictionistas will bring chewed Crayolas and well-thumbed stage plays on request. Menu Starters of Kinder Surprise fortune cookies and a bittersweet cocktail help un-clarify things as we begin the evening in a state of flux. Our main course will sort the grown-ups from the child-at-hearts as guests are served either steak with frites and sauce or bangers and mash with gravy. Both accompanied by spring veg and a warm beetroot and red onion salad. Calming things down for dessert, we offer up Mum's 'Early Bird' - ile flottante - served in large bowls to share, because by then you'll have learned how to share. Tickets included food and literary entertainment. In partnership with:
